text:
PROFESSOR: For a many
turn coil the surface

used to define the flux linkage
is often geometrically complex.

For this three turn
coil the surface

is filled in by stringing yarn
between a vertical rod joining

the terminals in the external
region to points on the wire.

The surface is filled in by
connecting points on the rod

to points of increasing
distance along the wire.

We have wound the few
inductors of different lengths

a number of turns
on a wooden rod,

using copper wire covered
with enamel insulation.

The enamel insulation
prevents electrical contact

between turns so the current
path must follow the wire.

The insulation prevents short
circuiting between turns.

We will measure the coil
inductance using this meter.

We have twisted the
terminal lens of this coil
to reduce the stray inductance.

It is wound on the
non magnetic rod which
has a radius of 5 millimeters.

This coil has 50 turns and
is 5.05 centimeters long.

The coil inductance is
predicted to be 4.9 microhenrys.

The inductance meter
measures the coil inductance
at 1 kilohertz.

This frequency is high enough
that the coil inductive

reactants greatly exceeds
the small coil of resistance,

which we have neglected
in our analysis.
We measure 5.9 microhenrys.

This inductance has
contributions from the coil
and connecting wires.

We short circuit the terminals
and measure 0.7 microhenrys

as the lead
inductance, subtracting

this from the measured
5.9 microhenrys

gives the coil inductance
is 5.2 microhenrys.

A reasonable agreement with
the predicted 4.9 microhenrys.

We now measure the
inductance of the coil

with double the number of turns,
but also double the length.

Doubling the number
of turns N but also

doubling the coil
length D should result
in double the inductance.

The inductance meter now reads
11.2 microhenrys subtracting

the 0.7 microhenrys
lead inductance

gives corrected coil
inductance of 10.5 microhenrys,

about double the inductance
of the first coil of 5.2
microhenrys, as it should be.

We now measure the
inductance of the coil which

is the same length
as the second coil,

but has two layers of
windings and thus double
the number of turns.

We measure 44.4 microhenrys
for which the corrected coil
inductance is 43.7 microhenrys.

We have doubled
the number of turns

without changing
the coil length.

The coil area of
the two layer coil

has hardly changed
because the wire diameter

is much smaller than the wood
diameter used as a core form.

The induction should
increase by 4.

This coil inductance is about
4 times our previous corrected

measurement of 10.5 microhenrys
with half the number of turns.

The surface for many turn
coil used in Faraday's law

is geometrically complex as the
bounding contour to the surface
follows the path of the wire.

For a tightly wound
coil the magnetic flux

linking this surface is the sum
of fluxes linking each turn.

Since the magnetic
flux per turn is

proportional to the
number of turns,

if each turn links
the same flux,

the total flux
linked by the coil
is N times the flux per turn.

The coil self-inductance is
then proportional to the square
of the number of turns.
